Dear Mr. Gonzalez:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
March 16, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and
lines of authority.
Five of thirty-one employee files reviewed lacked documentation
of verification the employee was provided a job description
through the agency. It should be noted the five employee files
that were missing this documentation were federal volunteer
workers that were supporting the staffing ratio. The facility did
review an orientation with these federal employees but did not
provide a specific job description for their role.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
Five of thirty-one employee files reviewed lacked documentation
of verification of education. It should be noted the five employee
files that were missing this documentation were federal
volunteer workers that were supporting the staffing ratio.
(d) Work history.
Five of thirty-one employee files reviewed lacked documentation
of verification of the employee’s work history. It should be noted
the five employee files that were missing this documentation
were federal volunteer workers that were supporting the staffing
ratio.
4

(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.
Five of thirty-one employee files reviewed lacked documentation
of verification of three dated references. It should be noted the
five employee files that were missing this documentation were
federal volunteer workers that were supporting the staffing ratio.
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian
province, or other country where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state
police records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or
other country law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
Five of thirty-one employee files reviewed lacked documentation
of verification a criminal background check was completed on
the employee directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency. It should be noted the
five employee files that were missing this documentation were
federal volunteer workers that were supporting the staffing ratio.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has not
been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
Eight of thirty-one employee files reviewed lacked
documentation of verification the employee has not been
determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or neglect as
required. It should be noted that five of the employee files that
were missing this documentation were federal volunteer workers
that were supporting the staffing ratio. The other three
employees had been with the agency for over a year. The three
staff member had clearances completed in the year of 2020 but
were missing their updated clearances for the year of 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary period
or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a written
evaluation of the employee’s performance annually
thereafter.
One of thirty-one employee files reviewed requiring an
evaluation lacked an evaluation completed by the facility within
180 days. This one employee file was a new staff member that
did not have a written evaluation completed within 180 days as
required.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that
each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of forty-five employee files reviewed where the employee
was employed for over a year lacked documentation of
verification of freedom of tuberculosis every one year as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2021 Interim, CAP approval date 03/21/2021
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all
of the following information shall be documented in the
case record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the
services provided while in residence, including medical and
dental services.
6

(c) An assessment of the residents needs that remain to
be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental follow up
that is needed, have been reviewed with the resident and
with the parent and with the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
One of eight closed residential youth files were reviewed lacked
the required discharge plan information in subsections (a)
through (f).

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
- Provided suggestions on obtaining documentation from the federal government
prior to the federal workers starting at the facility for support. The federal
government noted to the facility that the employees had background clearances
but did not provide the specific state clearances on criminal and abuse and
neglect requirements.
- Provided suggestion to update the policy around federal employees working at the
facility. It was suggested that during the orientation that a job description is to be
provided and signed for the employee’s file.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
- The facility was not in need of consultation.
7

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility had two special investigations during this period under review with one
resulting in a corrective action plan. The non-compliances included staff not following
Bethany Christian Services Cell Phone Policy. The facility’s corrective action plan
compliance is monitored quarterly and have completed all current corrective action plans.
The facility had four violations noted within their 2021 Interim Inspection. These
violations were due to not having documentation of verification the employee has not
been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or neglect as required, employees
having updated tuberculosis screens, new staff having the required 16 hours of
orientation training, and resident’s having an admission report completed within 7
calendar days of admission. The facility created a corrective action plan for the
violations and will still need to continue to work on having employee records in
compliance with the rules. It is noted in this inspection many of the employee record
issues resulted from the facility utilizing federal workers within their facility.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator noted over this reporting period COVID-19 has continued to be a
significant factor in staffing turnover and impacting services on their system. Over the
reporting period the facility has also had more admissions of residents that have
higher needs. The facility continues to work with their Human Resource department to
hire staff that meet the cultural and language needs of the residents they serve. Over
the reporting period the facility has also implemented “Annual Days” which help with
tracking their trainings and documentation for compliance.
Interviews:
Staff and youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and had no issues or
concerns were raised. During interviews with youth, they reported feeling safe at
Bridgeway and liking everything about the program thus far. Staff were viewed to be
meeting the needs of the children and interacting with them on a one-to-one basis.
The staff all reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well as
administration.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
